item.description:
Is there doubt that at least some of the insurrectionists would have killed congresspeople if they had the chance? Maybe it was all bluster, but imho probably not.

And if it's true, then the police at the Capitol, by holding back the mob, very much saved our country. https://t.co/g1J4YXF584
item.source:markdown:
Is there doubt that at least some of the insurrectionists would have killed congresspeople if they had the chance? Maybe it was all bluster, but imho probably not.
And if it's true, then the police at the Capitol, by holding back the mob, very much saved our country. https://t.co/g1J4YXF584

item.description: @rozzie ray, looking back -- the joy of writing for teletypes is there were no guis or clipboards or undo, or keeping various nodes in sync, so you could write something in an afternoon that people would love. ;-)
item.source:markdown: @rozzie ray, looking back -- the joy of writing for teletypes is there were no guis or clipboards or undo, or keeping various nodes in sync, so you could write something in an afternoon that people would love. ;-)

item.description: This might be the best line I ever wrote about working on standards. https://t.co/X0jNXERNs4
item.source:markdown: This might be the best line I ever wrote about working on standards. https://t.co/X0jNXERNs4

item.description:
It's fun crawling through the rubble that remains from the weirdness in the RSS world 20 or so years ago.

In hindsight -- the attempts to take over RSS failed.

Mostly they were not well thought-out imho.

RSS is massive. You can't even influence it much less take it over.

The validator situation is pretty bad. Apparently the original feed validator isn't working, the W3C put up a fork of it a while back, but it seems to be giving different advice now. That's embarrassing for a frozen format.

I think perhaps one of our projects should be to write an apolitical feed validator. From the point of view of apps that have to understand feeds. Wholly pragmatic. If you follow this advice your feeds will work well with the software that reads feeds.

This could be where all the reader apps get together. I wonder how much they share info with each other. I have no idea because literally none of them talk to me.
item.source:markdown:
It's fun crawling through the rubble that remains from the weirdness in the RSS world 20 or so years ago.
In hindsight -- the attempts to take over RSS failed.
Mostly they were not well thought-out imho.
RSS is massive. You can't even influence it much less take it over.
The validator situation is pretty bad. Apparently the original feed validator isn't working, the W3C put up a fork of it a while back, but it seems to be giving different advice now. That's embarrassing for a frozen format.
I think perhaps one of our projects should be to write an apolitical feed validator. From the point of view of apps that have to understand feeds. Wholly pragmatic. If you follow this advice your feeds will work well with the software that reads feeds.
This could be where all the reader apps get together. I wonder how much they share info with each other. I have no idea because literally none of them talk to me.

item.description: @JoeTrippi Joe -- that's why when I hear the pundits state almost as fact that the Dems are going to be wiped out in Nov I want to hurl. They should stick to reporting news. As in facts. ;-)
item.source:markdown: @JoeTrippi Joe -- that's why when I hear the pundits state almost as fact that the Dems are going to be wiped out in Nov I want to hurl. They should stick to reporting news. As in facts. ;-)

item.description: I love NYC, it’s where I am from, but I’m sorry this is the kind of self important idiot NY culture breeds. He has no idea how idiotic he is is. The people in the audience pity him, they laugh at him, he thinks he’s smart and handsome. Deluded poor idiot. https://t.co/CTzaaDw7uW
item.source:markdown: I love NYC, it’s where I am from, but I’m sorry this is the kind of self important idiot NY culture breeds. He has no idea how idiotic he is is. item.description: “An obituary of the actor Tony Dow was published in error. The Times based the confirmation of his death on a Facebook post by his representatives, which proved erroneous and has since been deleted.” https://t.co/hoLyAFa9gk
